question1.question: Which Scanner method reads an integer from console?

feedback.1: next() reads a token as String.
feedback.2: nextLine() reads a full line.

question2.question: True/False: FileInputStream reads character data only.

feedback.1: Incorrect. FileInputStream reads bytes.
feedback.2: Correct! It handles raw bytes, not just characters.

question3.question: Which class provides methods for modern file operations in Java NIO.2?

feedback.1: No. FileInputStream is for byte streams.
feedback.2: Correct! Files contains NIO.2 file utilities.
feedback.4: BufferedWriter is for buffered character output.

question4.question: True/False: try-with-resources automatically closes declared resources.

feedback.1: Correct! It ensures resources are closed.
feedback.2: Incorrect. try-with-resources closes resources automatically.

question1.question: In a few words, what is Java? Pick the best answer.

options.1: A Programming Language 2 : Where I get my Coffee from 3 : Something that prints %'Hello, World!%'

feedback.1: Correct! Java is a Programming Language.
feedback.2: While that may be true, that's very different from the Java we're talking about.
feedback.3: Sure, Java can do that, but it does a lot more too!

question2.question: Java is a relatively niche, unknown programming language.

feedback.1: Not quite. Java is one of the most popular coding languages used today and is anything but %'niche%'.
feedback.2: Correct! Java is proudly boasted to %'run on more than 60 billion machines worldwide%', and is one of the most popular coding languages used today.

question3.question: Which of these programs or systems was made with Java?

feedback.1: Actually, all of these are written with Java! Nice Job!
feedback.2: Actually, all of these are written with Java! Nice Job!
feedback.3: Actually, all of these are written with Java! Nice Job!
feedback.4: Actually, all of these are written with Java! Nice Job!

question1.question: What is the purpose of a constructor?

feedback.1: Not quite. Classes define types, constructors initialize instances.
feedback.2: Correct! A constructor sets up a new object's initial state.
feedback.3: Object destruction is handled by garbage collection.
feedback.4: Static methods are independent of constructors.

question2.question: True/False: Static methods can directly access instance variables.

feedback.1: Incorrect. Static methods belong to the class and can't access instance-specific data.
feedback.2: Correct! They can only access static members directly.

question1.question: Which data structure follows Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) order?

feedback.1: Incorrect. Queues follow FIFO.
feedback.2: Correct! Stacks are LIFO.

question2.question: True/False: Generics in Java allow for defining methods that work with multiple data types.

feedback.1: Correct! Generics enable type parameters.
feedback.2: Incorrect. Generics enhance flexibility.

question3.question: Which implementation offers O(1) random access but O(n) insertion in the middle?

feedback.1: LinkedList has O(n) access.
feedback.2: Correct! ArrayList has fast access but slow middle inserts.
feedback.3: HashSet is unordered. 4 : TreeMap is a sorted map.

question4.question: In a HashMap, what happens when two keys have the same hash code?

options.2: They collide and stored in the same bucket

feedback.1: Incorrect. Colliding keys coexist.
feedback.2: Correct! They go into the same bucket.
feedback.4: Resize happens when load factor exceeded.

question5.question: True/False: A Deque can only add and remove elements at one end.

feedback.1: Incorrect. Deque supports both ends.
feedback.2: Correct! Deque is double-ended.

question6.question: Which wildcard allows reading from a collection of Number or its subclasses?

feedback.1: ? is unbounded.
feedback.2: Correct! ? extends Number allows Number or subclass.

question1.question: Which term best describes a method that calls itself?

feedback.1: Iteration uses loops rather than self-calls.
feedback.2: Correct! Recursion is when a method calls itself.
feedback.3: Overloading involves multiple methods sharing a name.
feedback.4: Encapsulation bundles data and methods together.

question2.question: True/False: In Java, overloaded methods must have different parameter lists.

feedback.1: Correct! Overloaded methods differ by parameters.
feedback.2: Incorrect. They must differ in parameter lists.

question1.question: Select a real Java primitive type.

feedback.1: String is a very useful and common data type, but it is not a primitive in Java. Notice that String starts with a capital letter: that indicates it is an Object.
feedback.2: Correct! Floats are a primitive data type used to store numbers with decimal parts.
feedback.3: While %kint%/k is a primitive type, Integer is the associated wrapper type for int. Notice that Integer is capitalized, which indicates that it is an Object.
feedback.4: String (with a capital S) is an Object in Java, but string (with lowercase s) is not.

question2.question: True/False: To create an object instance, use the %kcreate%/k keyword.

feedback.1: Incorrect. To create an object instance, we use the %knew%/k keyword.
feedback.2: That's right. To create an object instance, we use the %knew%/k keyword.

question3.question: True/False: Variables declared as %kfinal%/k are immutable and their value cannot be changed.

feedback.1: That's correct. Using the %kfinal%/k keyword makes a variable immutable and means its value cannot be reassigned.
feedback.2: Nope, %kfinal%/k variables are immutable with unchanging values.

question4.question: Which of these statements represents or involves a Widening conversion?

feedback.1: Incorrect. There is neither a widening nor a narrowing in this statement.
feedback.2: Not quite. This is a narrowing conversion, since we're taking a double (with a larger size) and making it an int (with a smaller size).
feedback.3: Though this looks like widening at first, this is actually a distinct concept called Autoboxing. Integer is a wrapper class which %icontains%/i the int value.
feedback.4: Correct! In this case, the (smaller) int value of 10 is being widened into the (larger) double value of 10.0.

question5.question: True/False: The name of the double type refers to the fact that it is double the size of a float.

feedback.1: That's correct. A float is 32 bits (4 bytes) in size while a double is 64 bits (8 bytes).
feedback.2: This statement is true. A float is 32 bits (4 bytes) in size while a double is 64 bits (8 bytes).

question_1.question: What keyword is used to define a class in Java?

feedback.3: Correct! 'class' is the keyword to define a class.

question_2.question: True/False: A 'while' loop always runs at least once.

feedback.2: Correct! Unlike 'do-while', 'while' might never run.

question_3.question: What is the return type of a method that doesn't return anything?

feedback.2: Correct! 'void' means no return value.

question_4.question: Which term best describes using the same method name with different parameters?

feedback.3: Correct! Overloading allows multiple method signatures.

question_5.question: True/False: Constructors have the same name as their class.

feedback.1: Correct! Constructors match the class name.

question_6.question: Which principle of OOP hides internal details?

question_7.question: Which keyword is used to create an interface in Java?

question_8.question: Which block always executes in exception handling?

question_9.question: True/False: FileReader is used to write data to a file.

feedback.2: Correct! FileReader is for reading.

question_10.question: Which class is used to take console input in Java?

question_11.question: Which data structure allows duplicate values and maintains order?

feedback.3: Correct! ArrayList supports duplicates and order.

question_12.question: True/False: Arrays can be resized after creation.

feedback.2: Correct! Arrays are fixed size.

question_13.question: What is the default initial capacity of an ArrayList in Java?

question_14.question: Which class is thread-safe for concurrent hash-based maps?

question_15.question: True/False: Generic classes allow you to define type-safe templates.

feedback.1: Correct! Generics improve type safety.

question1.question: Which keyword declares that a method may throw a checked exception?

feedback.1: Incorrect. 'throw' raises an exception instance.
feedback.2: Correct! 'throws' declares checked exceptions.
feedback.3: 'try' starts a block for catching exceptions.

question2.question: True/False: Unchecked exceptions must be declared in the method signature.

feedback.1: Incorrect. Unchecked exceptions need not be declared.
feedback.2: Correct! Only checked exceptions require declaration.

question1.question: What does the 'implements' keyword indicate in Java?

feedback.1: Not quite. 'extends' is for inheritance.
feedback.2: Correct! 'implements' signals interface adoption.

question2.question: True/False: Abstract classes can contain both abstract and concrete methods.

feedback.1: Correct! Abstract classes mix method types.
feedback.2: Incorrect. They can have concrete methods too.

feedback.1: Correct! int[][] a declares a 2D array.
feedback.2: That's 3D.

feedback.1: Correct! Lists allow duplicates.
feedback.2: Incorrect. ArrayList can contain duplicates.

question3.question: Which class provides utility methods for arrays?

feedback.1: Collections is for collections, not arrays.
feedback.2: Correct! Arrays has methods like sort and binarySearch.

question4.question: What happens when you access index -1 in an array?

feedback.1: No, index starts at 0.
feedback.2: Correct! Negative index is out of bounds.
feedback.4: It's a runtime exception, not compile-time.

feedback.1: Incorrect. HashSet is unordered.
feedback.2: Correct! Use LinkedHashSet for insertion order.

question1.question: Which loop should you use when you know exactly how many times to iterate?

feedback.1: Not quite. While loops are great when we donâ€™t know how many times we need to loop.
feedback.2: Correct! The for loop is best when we know the exact number of iterations.
feedback.3: Do-while loops ensure at least one iteration but are not necessarily best when we know the count.
feedback.4: The for-each loop is great for collections but not for a fixed number of iterations.

question2.question: True/False: The 'break' statement skips the rest of the current loop iteration and moves to the next one.

feedback.1: Incorrect. 'break' completely exits the loop, while 'continue' skips to the next iteration.
feedback.2: That's right! 'break' stops the loop entirely, while 'continue' moves to the next iteration.
